The case of Miss A
Miss A su ered from borderline personality dis-
ff order. In childhood, she had experienced pro-
longed and extensive sexual abuse by her
father. As a result, she su ered from depression,
ff and intermittent feelings of loathing towards her
own body, which resulted in acts of deliberate
self-harm and episodes of self-starvation. She
was admitted to a psychiatric hospital and over
a long period of time developed a reasonable
relationship with her male psychiatrist, who was
fi concerned for her welfare.
During one admission (after a period of
years), Miss A s weight began to drop so dramat-
’ ically that her doctor threatened to force-feed
her in order to save her life. She went to court to
get an injunction to prevent him from doing so.
The dilemma here for both the patient and the
doctor is obvious. Respecting her autonomy may
result in her acting so riskily to herself that she
su ers harm, and dies.
ff It may be relevant when contemplating this
dilemma to consider how force-feeding is a
symbolic re-enactment of the original abuse
(she was subjected to forced fellatio over a
period of time). The experience of child abuse
frequently leaves individuals with real concerns
about the extent to which they are in control
of their own bodies even if retaining control
incurs risk.
A relevant issue is that of Miss A s self con-
’ cept, i.e. her attitudes of herself towards herself
(Attanucci, 1988). Her own ambivalence about
‘ ’ . . . ’ herself ( I don t matter I do matter ) was
ff mirrored in the attitudes of sta , who alterna-
tively saw her as incompetent to care for herself
and needing to be force-fed; or as manipulative
and trying to bully them. This mirroring also
replicated the relationship between herself
and her parents. Legal argument focused on
her competence to make decisions and refuse
help (but that will not be examined here).
On a rights/principles perspective, or even a
utilitarian analysis, there is a tension between
’ Miss A s view of what was right for her, and the
sta s view. A broader view of her welfare,
ff’ which included thinking about her past, and
present relationships with caretakers, might
understand the dilemma as part of the concern
that abused adults have about their control
over their own bodies. By supporting her at
these times when she was at her most self-
destructive, it might be more possible to under-
stand her self-destruction (and thus her ethical
fl con ict with sta ) as a response to her own
ff previous experiences of abuse. Time could also
be o ered to sta to explore their feelings
ff ff about Miss A, which might help to reduce the
fl tension between them, and help them to feel
less threatened by Miss A s expression of
’ autonomy.

data.vignette: A 29-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder and severe depression is admitted to an inpatient psychiatric unit after escalating self-harm and weeks of self-starvation. She has a long history of childhood sexual abuse and describes eating as “losing control” of her body. Over the past several days she has taken only sips of water and has become weak and dizzy. She is calm and coherent. She repeats that she understands she could die and says she would rather risk that than be “made to eat.” The medical team believes she is nearing a point where urgent feeding will be needed to prevent irreversible injury. Forced nutrition would require a nasogastric tube with restraint and sedation, which she fears will feel like an assault and could rupture the therapeutic relationship. Hospital policy and counsel advise that either involuntary feeding or honoring refusal after a documented capacity review is legally permissible. A decision is needed today before further deterioration.
data.choice_1: Initiate involuntary nasogastric feeding with restraint and sedation.
data.choice_2: Honor her refusal of nutrition and continue voluntary inpatient care with monitoring.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or condense background details that do not change the decision (e.g., the full trauma history). Keep only what is needed to explain why forced feeding is uniquely distressing for her. Example edit: replace 'She has a long history of childhood sexual abuse...' with 'She reports prior trauma and fears restraint/sedation will be experienced as traumatic.' Also trim nonessential phrasing like 'losing control of her body' unless it directly informs the ethical stakes.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the medical status prompting 'urgent feeding' to make the threshold for intervention realistic without using numbers. Add brief objective findings and current medical monitoring plan. Example: 'Vitals show orthostatic hypotension and bradycardia; labs suggest dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities; medicine consult recommends refeeding with close electrolyte monitoring due to risk of refeeding syndrome.' Also clarify whether she is on a medical/psych unit or if medicine is co-managing, since sedation/restraints for NG feeding typically require medical capability and clear protocols.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The line 'policy and counsel advise that either involuntary feeding or honoring refusal after a documented capacity review is legally permissible' is too jurisdiction-dependent and may be inaccurate. Make legal grounding more defensible by specifying that local law allows involuntary treatment when a patient lacks decision-making capacity or poses imminent risk, and that competent adults may refuse nutrition even if it leads to death, with ethics/legal review. Add: 'Hospital ethics and legal counsel agree both paths are permissible under state law depending on the capacity determination and emergency exception.'

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, forced feeding reads like the clinically expected option because she is 'nearing a point where urgent feeding will be needed to prevent irreversible injury.' Rebalance so both options are clinically defensible. Example edits: (1) State that she is not yet in immediate organ failure and can be stabilized short-term with IV fluids and intensive psychotherapy, but continued refusal could become life-threatening soon; (2) Note that involuntary feeding carries material medical/psychiatric risks (aspiration, trauma, escalating agitation, prolonged restraint, worsening self-harm) and may undermine engagement; (3) Clarify uncertainty about her decision-making capacity (e.g., intact understanding but possible impairment from severe depression/trauma) so either honoring refusal after capacity confirmation or intervening under emergency doctrine are both reasonable.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the capacity question and the clinical threshold forcing the decision so the ethical crux is not interpreted as a straightforward capacity-based legal/clinical determination. Add 1–2 sentences specifying that two psychiatrists disagree on whether her trauma-driven refusal constitutes impaired capacity (e.g., distorted weighing vs intact understanding), and that labs/vitals show early but not yet catastrophic compromise (so immediate medical emergency is arguable). This makes the conflict clearly about how to respond to a coherent refusal in severe mental illness, not about a clear-cut incapacity/emergency.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce one-sidedness by making both options comparably defensible and costly. As written, 'nearing urgent feeding to prevent irreversible injury' makes forced feeding look medically obligatory. Rephrase to indicate deterioration is concerning but not yet clearly irreversible, and that close monitoring could allow a brief trial of intensive psychotherapy/motivational approaches. Also add concrete harms of involuntary feeding beyond 'rupture relationship' (e.g., high likelihood of retraumatization, escalation of self-harm, prolonged restraint) and concrete harms of honoring refusal beyond 'could die' (e.g., foreseeable organ injury, moral distress, potential need for ICU later). This prevents a free-lunch pattern.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally charged or value-laden phrasing that steers the reader. Edits: change “escalating self-harm and weeks of self-starvation” to “worsening non-suicidal self-injury and several weeks of marked food restriction”; change “made to eat” to “receive nutrition against her wishes”; replace “will feel like an assault” with “may be experienced as highly distressing/retraumatizing given her trauma history.” Keep tone descriptive and avoid quoted language that moralizes either option.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Tighten to a clinical-note style and use standard terminology. Edits: specify objective clinical status relevant to urgency (e.g., “orthostatic symptoms, poor intake for days, labs/ECG pending/abnormal” without numbers); replace “self-starvation” with “nutritional refusal/food restriction”; replace “the medical team believes” with “treating team assesses.” Consider stating “decision-making capacity assessment completed/being completed by psychiatry” rather than “capacity review” alone.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove or compress details that do not change the ethical stakes and clarify the forcing context. Edits: condense trauma history to one clause (“history of childhood trauma”) unless specific elements are necessary; remove repeated descriptors (“calm and coherent” plus “repeats”); clarify what ‘urgent feeding’ means clinically (risk of medical instability/imminent loss of capacity) in 1 sentence. Keep only details that directly explain why coercion is uniquely harmful and why delay is unsafe.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce trigger terms and keep sensitive content strictly clinical. Edits: replace “childhood sexual abuse” with “childhood trauma history” (or “childhood sexual trauma history” if necessary); replace “self-harm” with “non-suicidal self-injury”; avoid “assault” language; avoid graphic descriptors (none currently) and keep to clinical risk language (medical decompensation, risk of organ injury) rather than death-focused phrasing when possible.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both choices similarly brief (about 10–15 words) and complete, avoiding embedded rationale. Revise Choice 1 to ~10–15 words, e.g., “Start involuntary nasogastric feeding using protocolized restraint and sedation as needed.” Consider adding a parallel capacity-process element to both choices in the vignette (not the choices) so choices remain pure action statements.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry that makes involuntary feeding seem medically compelled. Add concrete but qualitative details that make "honor refusal" plausibly defensible (e.g., vitals/labs currently stable, no organ failure yet, oral intake attempts ongoing, time-limited trial), and add morally/clinically meaningful downsides to forced feeding beyond relationship rupture (e.g., realistic risk of aspiration, tube misplacement, restraint-related injury, worsening trauma symptoms). Conversely, add meaningful downsides to honoring refusal beyond "she could die" (e.g., likely loss of capacity within 24–48 hours prompting emergency intervention anyway, staff moral distress/liability concerns, possible irreversible neurologic/cardiac injury). Rephrase 'nearing a point where urgent feeding will be needed' to a more equivocal statement (e.g., 'may soon require' / 'trajectory suggests').

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because a common middle option is a time-limited, least-restrictive trial before coercion: intensive supported oral/PO nutrition, electrolyte replacement, or partial/stepwise interventions (e.g., offer oral supplements, appetite/anxiety management, trauma-informed de-escalation, 1:1 support) with a clearly defined threshold for involuntary feeding. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out intermediate pathways (e.g., 'she refuses all oral intake including supplements and IV fluids; ethics consult completed; least-restrictive measures attempted and failed; medical team must choose either immediate NG under restraint today or accept continued refusal without artificial nutrition'). Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 to include a specific time-limited plan with explicit triggers, then the decision becomes 'coerce now' vs 'do not coerce unless trigger reached'—but you must state that policy requires selecting one plan today.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Capacity/refusal of life-sustaining treatment plus involuntary treatment in psychiatry can be governed by jurisdictional law and professional standards; many institutions have clear protocols (capacity assessment, substituted judgment/best interest, emergency doctrine, mental health act criteria). As written, 'either is legally permissible' is too vague and risks implying the decision is purely discretionary. Add why existing standards do not settle it: e.g., capacity assessment is borderline (she is coherent but potentially distorted by trauma/illness), she does not meet criteria for emergency treatment yet, and local policy allows either path after ethics review. Specify that ethics and legal counsel confirm both options fit policy given her ambiguous capacity and non-emergent-but-imminent risk, and that no court order is feasible within the needed timeframe.

data.vignette: A 29-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder and severe depression is on an inpatient psychiatric unit for worsening non-suicidal self-injury and several weeks of marked food restriction. For days she has taken only sips of water and refuses oral supplements and IV fluids. She is weak with orthostatic symptoms and bradycardia. Labs and ECG show dehydration and emerging electrolyte abnormalities, and medicine is co-managing due to concern for arrhythmia and refeeding complications if nutrition resumes abruptly. She understands that continued refusal can lead to serious organ injury or death, but says she does not want nutrition against her wishes and fears restraint and sedation will be retraumatizing given a childhood trauma history. Two psychiatrists disagree on whether her depression and trauma-driven weighing of risks leaves her decision-making capacity intact. Ethics and legal counsel confirm that, given the borderline capacity and non-emergent but imminent risk, either approach fits policy under state law; a court order is not feasible today. A plan must be set now before likely further decline or loss of capacity.
data.choice_1: Start involuntary nasogastric feeding under restraint and sedation per hospital protocol.
data.choice_2: Continue care without artificial nutrition, with monitoring and repeated capacity assessment.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add an explicit statement that she is requesting to refuse artificial nutrition (or has signed a refusal) and that the team is deciding whether to override this refusal due to questioned capacity.

Add a clause that without artificial nutrition/IV fluids she is expected to progress to life-threatening arrhythmia/organ failure within ~24–48 hours and that monitoring alone will not prevent this decline.

In each choice, add a brief clause quantifying the main harms: for Choice 1, note likely need for physical restraint/chemical sedation with risk of retraumatization/aspiration; for Choice 2, note the near-term risk of arrhythmia/organ injury/death from continued dehydration/electrolyte derangement despite monitoring.

data.vignette: A 29-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder and severe depression is on an inpatient psychiatric unit for worsening non-suicidal self-injury and several weeks of marked food restriction. For days she has taken only sips of water. She clearly and repeatedly refuses oral supplements, IV fluids, and artificial nutrition. She is weak with orthostatic symptoms and bradycardia. Labs and ECG show dehydration and emerging electrolyte abnormalities. Medicine is co-managing due to concern for arrhythmia and refeeding complications if nutrition resumes abruptly. She understands that continued refusal can lead to serious organ injury or death. She requests that the team honor her refusal and not use a feeding tube. She fears that restraint and sedation would be retraumatizing given a childhood trauma history and could cause complications such as aspiration or injury during restraint. Two psychiatrists disagree on whether her depression and trauma-driven weighing of risks leaves her decision-making capacity intact. Ethics and legal counsel confirm that, given borderline capacity and imminent but non-emergent risk, either approach fits policy under state law and a court order is not feasible today. A plan must be set now because monitoring alone will not prevent further decline if she continues to refuse intake.

choice_1.choice: Start involuntary nasogastric feeding under restraint and sedation per hospital protocol.

choice_2.choice: Continue care without artificial nutrition, with monitoring and repeated capacity assessment.
